pitrou commented on pull request #10503:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/10503#issuecomment-862191654


   It seems Pandas detects nulls in quoted strings. @jorisvandenbossche Do you think we should do differently by default?
   ```python
   >>> s = '''a,b\n1.0,"foo"\n"N/A","N/A"'''
   >>> df = pd.read_csv(io.BytesIO(s.encode()))
   >>> df
        a    b
   0  1.0  foo
   1  NaN  NaN
   ```

fields.description:
When parsing my CSV I have set
{color:#267f99}ConvertOptions{color}::s{color:#001080}trings_can_be_null{color} to true.

Now as I have values:
{code:java}
1234,"",345
{code}
the string value which is an empty string is treated as NULL.
I've checked default valeus of {color:#267f99}ConvertOptions{color}::{color:#001080}null_values{color} and there is empty string considered null, but here we have empty quoted string which shouldn't be treated as NULL in my opinion. Similar behavior we have in Postgresql, empty quoted string is not treated as a NULL: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/sql-copy.html
fields.summary: [C++] CSV empty quoted string is treated as NULL

comments.body:
That sounds like a reasonable request.
[~npr] do you think this can be unconditional, or should there be a configuration option for it?

If ParseOptions::quoting is true, then empty quoted string should be interpreted as empty string, and thus null by default, right? 

I'm not sure I understand the expected behavior that can't be achieved with a combination of the existing options. (And full disclosure, I also don't understand what strings_can_be_null is for if you can also specify the strings that mean null.)

> If ParseOptions::quoting is true, then empty quoted string should be interpreted as empty string, and thus null by default, right? 

Yes. The issue is asking for the converse (quoted strings should never be null).

> (And full disclosure, I also don't understand what strings_can_be_null is for if you can also specify the strings that mean null.) 

You can have other columns than strings. So you may want to detect nulls in those columns but not in string columns (where even "N/A" etc. will be regular strings).
What is the current state of this issue, do you think it will be fixed?
It can definitely be fixed, I was just hoping for feedback from other people.
[~wesm] What is your opinion on this?

For reference, it doesn't seem that pandas can handle this case. 

By default, empty strings are considered missing values:

{code:python}
In [1]: s = """a,b,c
   ...: 1,"string",2
   ...: ,"",4"""

In [2]: pd.read_csv(StringIO(s))
Out[2]: 
     a       b  c
0  1.0  string  2
1  NaN     NaN  4
{code}

You can specify a quoting keyword, but that only has influence in this case when indicating there is no quoting (meaning that the quotes become part of the data values):

{code}
In [3]: import csv

In [4]: pd.read_csv(StringIO(s), quoting=csv.QUOTE_NONE)
Out[4]: 
     a         b  c
0  1.0  "string"  2
1  NaN        ""  4
{code}

So this actually "achieves" the goal of not interpreting the quoted empty string as missing value, but now you would need to manually strip all quotes after reading to get rid of the quotes again.

There is also the option to specify which values to recognize as missing, so we can override the default of interpreting an empty string. But, then also "empty" slots for non-string columns get interpreted as an empty string, making that full column string (eg in this case the first numeric column gets interpreted wrongly):

{code}
In [5]: pd.read_csv(StringIO(s), na_values=[], keep_default_na=False)
Out[5]: 
   a       b  c
0  1  string  2
1             4

In [6]: pd.read_csv(StringIO(s), na_values=[], keep_default_na=False).values
Out[6]: 
array([['1', 'string', 2],
       ['', '', 4]], dtype=object)
{code}

So the goal of specifying _"don't interpret quoted empty string as missing value, but still interpret any other empty string as such"_ cannot be directly achieved with pandas. 
It does sound potentially useful to be able to do if you have such a file, but no idea how common this would be.
I agree that it should be possible (and hopefully straightforward) to interpret empty quoted strings as non-null.
